document.docTitle: Description of the second species of Synhalcurias Carlgren, 1914, Synhalcurias kahakui sp. nov. (Actiniaria: Actinernidae) with redescription of S. elegans (Wassilieff, 1908)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Description of the second species of Synhalcurias Carlgren, 1914, Synhalcurias kahakui sp. nov. (Actiniaria: Actinernidae) with redescription of S. elegans (Wassilieff, 1908)

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Molecular Invertebrate Systematics and Ecology Laboratory, Department of Biology, Chemistry, and Marine Sciences, Faculty of Science, University of the Ryukyus, Nishihara, Okinawa 903-0213, Japan.
Coastal Branch of Natural History Museum and Institute, Chiba, Katsuura, Chiba 299-5242, Japan.

docTitle.emphasis:
Description of the second species of
Synhalcurias Carlgren, 1914
,
Synhalcurias kahakui
sp. nov. ( Actiniaria : Actinernidae ) with redescription of
S. elegans ( Wassilieff, 1908 )

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Molecular Invertebrate Systematics and Ecology Laboratory, Department of Biology, Chemistry, and Marine Sciences, Faculty of Science, University of the Ryukyus, Nishihara, Okinawa 903-0213, Japan .
Coastal Branch of Natural History Museum and Institute, Chiba , Katsuura, Chiba 299-5242, Japan .

subSection.paragraph:
We describe a new sea anemone species,
Synhalcurias kahakui
sp. nov.
, from specimens collected off Otouto-jima and Amami-oshima islands in July 2016 and May 2019 . respectively. These sea anemones were identified as belonging to family Actinernidae due to their many endocoelic perfect mesenteries and identified as belonging to the genus
Synhalcurias Carlgren, 1914
because they have an oral disc without any developed lobes. Though this genus presently accommodates only one species,
Synhalcurias elegans ( Wassilieff, 1908 )
, our specimens are smaller than the aforementioned species, have fewer mesenteries, lack nematocyst batteries on the column, and have two types of microbasic p -mastigophores on the mesenterial filaments. These specimens are described as
Synhalcurias kahakui
sp. nov.
In view of the new species, the diagnosis of genus
Synhalcurias
is revised. In addition, we redescribe
S. elegans
based on newly specimens collected from Japan .
Key words: Taxonomy, Anenthemonae , genus revision, Ogasawara Islands, Pacific, R/V Koyo , R/V Toyoshio-Maru

The most distinct feature of the actiniarian family
Actinernidae Stephenson, 1922
is the mesenterial arrangement: the mesenteries in second and third cycle develop in the endocoels of the first cycle mesenteries ( Uchida, 2007 ). The development of endocoelic mesenteries is uncommon in actiniarians other than those belonging to Actinernidae and
Halcuriidae Carlgren, 1918
; as a rule, mesenteries younger than first 12 grow in exocoels between pairs of mesenteries of the first cycle. Thus, these two families form an independent suborder,
Endocoelantheae Carlgren, 1925
. However, recent phylogenetic analyses revealed these two families to be related to Edwardsiidae Andress, 1881 (
Rodríguez et al. , 2014
), and thus currently Actinernidae and Halcuriidae form the superfamily
Actinernoidea Stephenson, 1922
within the suborder
Anenthemonae Rodríguez and Daly, 2014
. There are presently four genera and nine species in the family Actinernidae ( Fautin, 2016 ;
Izumi et al. , 2019
; Gusmão and Rodríguez, 2021 ). In Japan , a total of five species in four genera have been recorded:
Actinernus robustus ( Hertwig, 1882 )
;
Isactinernus quadrilobatus Carlgren, 1918
;
Synactinernus flavus Carlgren, 1918
;
Synactinernus churaumi Izumi and Fujii, 2019
; and
Synhalcurias elegans ( Wassilieff, 1908 )
. The Japanese actinernid fauna includes representatives within all genera in this family, and two genera,
Synactinernus Carlgren, 1914
and
Isactinernus Carlgren, 1918
, are endemic to Japan (
Izumi et al. , 2019
). Thus, the diversity of Actinernidae can be considered to be highest in Japanese waters.

The genus
Synhalcurias Carlgren, 1914
was established to accommodate an actinernid sea anemone characterized by an oral disc without any lobes,
IIyanthopsis elegans Wassilieff, 1908
[=
Synhalcurias elegans ( Wassilieff, 1908 )
]. Although having a rounded oral disc without lobes is common among most sea anemones, this simple shape is distinct within Actinernidae because the other three genera have more or less lobed oral discs ( Carlgren, 1949 ;
Izumi et al. , 2019
). N o additional species have been described in the century since the description of
S. elegans ( Fautin, 2016 )
.

During dredging surveys in southern Japan , we collected specimens of Actinernidae west off Otouto-jima Island, Ogasawara Islands, and west off Amami O-shima Island, Nansei Islands, Japan . Though these anemones resembled
Synhalcuarias elegans
, they were smaller in size than
S. elegans
and also differed in other morphological features. In the present study, we describe some of these specimens as a second species of
Synhalcurias
,
S. kahakui
sp. nov.
, and revise the diagnosis of the genus. In addition, we redescribe
S. elegans
based on newly collected specimens from several localities of Japan .

The holotype of
Synhalcurias kahakui
sp. nov.
was collected off Otouto-Jima Island, Ogasawara Islands, in the Pacific Ocean ( Fig. 1A ), at 157 m depth on July 11, 2016 , using a biological dredge onboard the R/V Koyo of Tokyo Metropolitan Ogasawara Fisheries Research Center, Tokyo Metropolis. The specimen was kept relaxed in trays or tanks until the tentacles were completely extended, and then it was anesthetized with magnesium sulfate solution. The whole body, except for two tentacles, was fixed in 10% (v/v) formalin solution with seawater; the two tentacles were dissected and preserved in 99.5% ethanol. The paratypes of the new species were collected west off Amami O-shima Island, Nansei Islands, in the Pacific Ocean ( Fig. 1C ), at 315 m depth on May 23, 2019 , using a biological dredge onboard the R/V Toyoshio-Maru of Hiroshima University. The specimens were processed similarly to the holotype except for final preservation: two of three specimens were fixed whole in 10% (v/v) formalin solution with seawater, and the third whole one was preserved in 99% ethanol. The holotype and one paratype specimen were deposited in the National Museum of Nature and Science, Tokyo , NSMT (NSMT-Co 1695, 1696), and the other paratypes were deposited in the Coastal Branch of Natural History Museum and Institute, Chiba , CMNH (CMNH- ZG 09759, 09760).

In addition, we obtained two specimens of
Synhalcurias elegans
: one was collected from Kumano-nada Sea, Mie Prefecture , as bycatch of trawling by fishers and kept in a tank at Takeshima Aquarium ( Aichi Pref. ); the other specimen was collected from Uragami ( Fig. 1B ), Wakayama and was kept alive at the Kushimoto Marine Park ( Wakayama Pref. ). These specimens were processed similarly to those of
S. kahakui
sp. nov.
and deposited in the same institution (NSMT-Co 1693, 1694).

The specimens of
Synhalcurias kahakui
sp. nov.
including holotype (NSMT-Co 1965) and specimens of
S. elegans
was processed for histological sections following methods in Presnell and Schreibman (1997) . The 10% formalin sea water solution was substituted for 70% ethanol and the specimens were dissected using tweezers and scissors; subsequently, selected parts of the specimens were dehydrated using a graded ethanol series and xylene, embedded in paraffin, and sliced into serial sections (10 µm thick) using a microtome. Sections were mounted on glass slides and stained with hematoxylin and eosin.

Type specimens of
Synhalcurias elegans ( Wassilieff, 1908 )
were examined at the Bavarian State Collection of Zoology ( ZSM : Zoologische Staatssammlung München), Munich, Germany , on October 2002 and 2005. Squashed preparations of cnidae were made from syntypes ZSM 20040147 and ZSM 20040148 (original Doflein’s specimens no. 157A and 167, respectively).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1. Localities of
Synhalcurias elegans
(gray stars) and
S. kahakui
sp. nov.
(black stars).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Suborder
ANENTHEMONAE
Rodríguez & Daly, 2014
in Rodríguez
et al. , 2014

Diagnosis. Column cylindrical, distally not expanded, nor forming lobes; with many simple tentacles . Mesenteries 68 to ca. 100, all mesenteries perfect and fertile. After formation of ten first pairs of mesenteries (1st and 2nd cycles), further mesenterial formation cyclical in each of eight lateral endocoels, similar to
Halcurias
. Two siphonoglyphs. Column ectoderm with or without small nematocyst batteries.
Cnidom: basitrichs, spirocysts, microbasic b -mastigophores, microbasic p -mastigophores (each in all tissue).
(Modified from Uchida [2007] , changes in bold )

Remarks.
Synhalcurias
has been recognized as monotypic since it was established by Carlgren (1914) (see also Carlgren, 1949 ; Fautin, 2016 ). In this study, we describe a second species for this genus,
S. kakahui
sp. nov.
To incorporate this additional species, we rearranged the diagnosis as below: 1) adding the cnidom; 2) added the case that not nematocyst batteries in the column; 3) revised that all mesenteries perfect (instead of “almost all”).
(Japanese name: seitaka-kawari-ginchaku)

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Ilyanthopsis elegans Wassilieff, 1908: 8
, textfigs 2–5, pl. 1 fig. 2, pl. 3 fig. 38, pl. 4 figs. 39, 40a, 40b.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Material examined. Types ( Fig. 2 ).
ZSM2004147 ( syntype ): specimen collected from Sagami Bay , Japan by Franz Doflein on
May 1904
.
ZSM2004148 ( syntype ): specimen collected from Sagami Bay , Japan , at
110 m
, by Allan Owston using his yacht “Golden Hind” on
July 24, 1902
.
Other specimens ( Fig. 3 ).
NSMT-Co 1693: from Mikawa Bay , specimen dissected and fixed by Takato Izumi on
June 1, 2016
. NSMT-Co 1694: collected January 2018 ,
at Uragami , Wakayama Prefecture , at
100–130 m
, by Isao Hirabayashi , and dissected and fixed by Takuma Fujii and Kensuke Yanagi on
May 22, 2018
.

Description .
External anatomy .
Body cylindrical ( Fig. 3A ), 7–15 cm in length and 50–100 mm in diameter in living specimens, 50–100 mm in length and 35–80 mm in diameter in preserved specimens. Column surface relatively smooth, wrinkled but without any structures. Ectoderm of column pale orange or yellow when alive ( Fig. 3A ), with sparse, small nematocyst batteries. The naked column opaque milky white. Basal disc in aboral end, thick, robust and adhesive ( Fig. 3A ). Distal column not developed into lobes ( Fig. 3B ). Tentacles 76–100 in number on oral disc, all marginal, in two rows. All tentacles 5–10 mm in length, pale orange in color, long and slender without any structures and no thickenings. Tentacles less contractile and less adhesive. Oral disc pale orange, with radial stripes corresponding to every tentacle. Mouth at center of oral disc, lip-like, pale orange and yellow in color ( Fig. 3A, B ).

Cnidom .
Basitrichs, spirocysts, microbasic b -mastigophores and microbasic p -mastigophores. See Table 1 and Fig. 4A–L for size and distribution. Spirocysts in the column of the syntype ( ZSM2004147 ) are slightly distinguished into three types : small, gracile, and robust ones
.

Distribution. Sagami Bay, Kanagawa Pref. and Suruga Bay, Shizuoka Pref. ( Wassilieff, 1908 ); Ogasawara Islands, Tokyo Met. ( Carlgren, 1918 ); Suruga Bay, Shizuoka Pref. , Taiji and Kushimoto, Wakayama Pref. , Enshu- Nada Sea, Aichi Pref. ( Uchida, 2007 ); Mikawa Bay, Aichi Pref. , and Uragami, Wakayama Pref. (present study), all in Japan . All localities situated off the Pacific coast of Japan except for the Ogasawara Islands (see remarks of
Synhalcurias kahakui
sp. nov.
).

Remarks. This species was originally described as
Ilyanthopsis elegans
by Wassilieff (1908) . However, this genus was abolished by Carlgren (1914) because its type species,
I. longifilis Hertwig (1888)
, had been already synonymized with
Condylactis passiflora Duchassaing and Michelotti, 1864
(currently considered a junior synonym of
Condylactis gigantea
[ Fautin, 2016 ]) by Pax (1910) . Thus, Carlgren established a new genus,
Synhalcurias Carlgren, 1914
, for
I. elegans
. This new genus was monotypic.

Since its original description and additional specimens in Carlgren (1918) ,
Synhalcurias elegans
had not subsequently been documented until Uchida (2007) ; he redescribed
S. elegans
using specimens collected from several localities of Japan (see distribution). The characters of our specimens almost perfectly correspond to the redescription of Uchida (2007) and the two syntypes . There is a slight difference in the cnidae between the type material, description of Uchida (2007) and our specimens: the spirocysts of the column can be distinguished into the three types in the type specimen (ZSM2004147), into two types according to Uchida (2007) , but are of only one type in our specimen (NSMT-Co 1693). However, there were several cnidae with intermediate form between the two types , thus this difference should not be a conclusive factor to differentiate the species. Thus, we identified these specimens as
S. elegans
, and redescribed this species by emending mesenterial arrangements and histology of the description of Uchida (2007) and added images of the cnidae. Note that Carlgren (1918) mentioned hermaphrodite specimens; we observed only gonochoric individuals and only immature spermatic cysts.

FIGURE 2 Two syntypes of
Synhalcurias elegans
deposited in Bavarian State Collection of Zoology (ZSM). A, Lateral view of syntype (ZSM20040148, original Doflein’s specimen no. 167); B, Lateral view of syntype (ZSM20040147, original Doflein’s specimen no. 157A).

FIGURE 3. External and internal views of
Synhalcurias elegans ( Wassilieff, 1908 )
. A, B, F, G, NSMT-Co 1693; C–E, NSMT- Co 1694. A, B, external views of
S. elegans
. A, lateral view; B, oral view. C–H, internal views. C, gross section of upper column; D, transversal section of macrocnemes at upper column; E, transversal section of macrocnemes at lower column; F, longitudinal section of a tentacle; G, transversal section of a tentacle. Abbreviations: a, actinopharynx; fi, filament; go, gonad; ma, macrocneme; me, mesoglea; pa, parietal muscle; rm, retractor muscle; s, siphonoglyph; te, tentacle. Scale bars indicate 5 cm in A and B, 1 cm in C, 1 mm in D and E; F, G, 50 µm.

FIGURE 4. The cnidoms of
Synhalcurias elegans
and
S. kahakui
. A–L, cnidom of
S. elegans
. A–C, tentacle. A, spirocyst; B, basitrich; C, microbasic b -mastigophore. D–F, Actinopharynx. D, spirocyst; E, basitrich; F, microbasic p -mastigophore. G–I, Column. G, spirocyst; H, basitrich; I, microbasic p -mastigophore. J–M, filament. J, spirocyst; K, basitrich; L, microbasic p - mastigophore. M–Y, cnidom of
S. kahakui
. M–O, tentacle. M, spirocyst; N, basitrich; O, microbasic b- mastigophore. P–R, Actinopharynx. P, spirocyst; Q, basitrich; R, microbasic p -mastigophore. S–U, Column. S, spirocyst; T, basitrich; U, microbasic p - mastigophore. V–Y, filament. V, spirocyst; W, basitrich; X, microbasic b -mastigophore; Y, microbasic p -mastigophore (large).

subSubSection.paragraph: (New Japanese name: kobito-seitaka-kawari-ginchaku)
Figs. 4 , 5 ; Table 1

Material examined.
Holotype .
NSMT-Co 1695: dissected specimen,
July 11, 2016
, off northwestern Otouto-jima Island , Ogasawara Islands ( 27°13.13ʹN , 142°5.43ʹE ), at
157 m
in depth, biological dredge, coll. T . Izumi
.
Paratypes .
NSMT-Co 1696: dissected specimen (damaged on its surface), collected
May 23, 2019
, west off Amami Island ( 28°22.42ʹN , 129°15.14ʹE ), at
315 m
in depth, using beam trawl, during research cruise of RV Toyoshio-Maru , coll. I. Kobayashi. CMNH-ZG 09759 : a dissected specimen and histological slides; same date, locality, collector, and method as NSMT-Co 1696. CMNH-ZG 09760 : a whole specimen preserved in 99 % ethanol; same date, locality, collector, and method as NSMT-Co 1696
.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5. External and internal views of
Synhalcurias kahakui
sp. nov.
(NSMT-Co 1695). A–C, External view. A, Whole living specimen of
S. kahakui
; B, oral view; C, preserved specimen. D–I internal view. D longitudinal section of tentacle; E, enlarged view of D; F, transverse section of tentacle; G, enlarged view of F; H. transverse section of actinopharynx; I, enlarged view of mesentery; J, transversal section of gamete (matured oocyte). Abbreviations: Ac, actinopharynx; Me, mesoglea; Oo, oocyte; Pm, parietal muscle; Rm, retractor muscle; Si, siphonoglyph; Te, tentacle. Scale bars: A–C, 1 cm; D, F, I, J, 200 µm; E, G, 50 µm; H, 1 mm.

TABLE 1. Size and distribution of cnidae in
Synhalcurias elegans
(NSMT-Co 1693, ZSM2004147) and
Synhalcurias kahakui
sp. nov.
(NSMT-Co 1695, CMNH-ZG 09759). Size range, Mean, and SD are dictated as length × width. A–Y indicate the figures of each cnida in Fig. 4.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Description. External anatomy.
Body cylindrical ( Fig. 5A, C ), up to ca. 50 mm in height and ca. 30 mm in width in preserved specimens; 40 mm in height and 27 mm in height and 15 mm in width in preserved holotype . Column surface smooth, without tenaculi or nematocyst batteries, pale whitish orange (or translucent) ectoderm layer and transversal discontinuous yellow line. Column has spirocysts and very sparsely distributed nematocysts. Surface of column easily peeled off. Distal column slightly expanded, simple and not developed into lobes ( Fig. 5B ). Tentacles simple, all marginal, 8–16 mm length, tapering at tip, no thickenings including at aboral base, pale white to pale orange in color when alive ( Fig. 5A–B ); 68 in number on oral disc; inner and outer tentacles alternatively bared. Tentacles less contractile and less adhesive. Aboral end developed as pedal disc, opaque, with mesenterial insertions invisible. Oral disc pale white, diameter almost same as column. Mouth at center of oral disc, highly swollen, lip-like, with radial grooves on surface, pale orange, with fluorescent yellow patch on dorsal and aboral sides when alive ( Fig. 5B ).

Cnidom .
basitrichs, spirocysts, microbasic b -mastigophores, and microbasic p -mastigophores. See Table 1 and Fig. 4M–Y for size and distribution.

Etymology. This species name is derived from the Japanese abbreviated name “Kahaku” of the National Museum of Nature and Science, Tokyo . The survey during which this species was collected was part of a project organized by this museum. Derivation of Japanese name: “kobito” means small, as
S. kahakui
sp. nov.
is far smaller than
S. elegans
.
Distribution. Off Ogasawara Islands, Tokyo Met., and Amami Island, Kagoshima Pref. Both localities are around remote islands south of the mainland of Japan ( Fig. 1 ).

Remarks. This species is remarkably similar to
S. elegans
and clearly belongs to
Synhalcurias
. However, there are several differences between
S. kahakui
sp. nov.
and
S. elegans
: the sizes of bodies (
S. kahakui
shorter than 50 mm when alive), even when at sexual maturity; the number of perfect mesenteries (
S. kahakui
has 68 (first to fourth cycle of mesenteries), whereas
S. elegans
has at least 76 (but up to 108); the column of
S. kahakui
has no nematocyst batteries.

subSection.paragraph:
We would like to acknowledge Yuhei Tanaka and staff and crew of R/V Koyo ( Tokyo Metropolitan Ogasawara Fisheries Research Center) for helping in collection of the holotype of
S. kahakui
and Itaru Kobayashi (University of Tokyo , NSMT), Susumu Otsuka and crew of R/V Toyoshio-Maru ( Hiroshima University) for collecting the paratype specimens. We also acknowledge Masato Todate (Takeshima Aquarium), Fishing boat Kiei-Maru, Isao Hirabayashi (Kushimoto Marine Park), and Takuma Fujii (International Center for Island Studies Amami Station, Kagoshima University) for collecting, keeping, or preserving the specimens of
S. elegans
. Dr. Ludwig Tiefenbacher ( ZSM ) kindly help us for the examination of type specimens, and we deeply thank him. Finally, we appreciate Toshihiko Fujita (NSMT) for financial aid and use of the budget below, as well as giving me advice to me several times during this study. James Davis Reimer (University of the Ryukyus) edited the English of the final version of this manuscript.

This study was supported by JSPS KAKENHI (Grants Number JP17 J03267 to TI), The National Museum of Nature and Science project research “Biological Properties of Biodiversity Hotspots in Japan ”, and partly by a grant from the Fujiwara Natural History Foundation to KY.
